commentBody:
Another fine Friday ... but it's not Groundhog Day.
Oh, well. 
Thanks, Mark.
I guarantee that most of the complaints today will be the PUTTEES/STUPA cross.

I have a strict no look up/no help policy. The only exception is things in my immediate field of vision. It just so happens I have an unopened/unread set of the Divergent book series on my book shelf. Would have needed all four crossings for that one otherwise...

It's so weird when you hear an obscure word and it ends up in the NYT crossword the next day. Yesterday, I was randomly watching a YouTube video of Andy Samburg being interviewed by Sesame Street's Bert, and Bert asked him, "If you could wear a sock from any time period, what sock would that be?" After Andy answered the modern sock, Bert said his choice would be the "fifth century PUTTEES." Then he spelled it! Thanks, Bert!
The ROSY BOA instantly made me think of this adorable moment with Zohran Mamdani and a little boy telling of his golden snake: https://youtu.be/pgxVmTADJPY

I found this one delightful from start to finish.  Despite the many decades of puzzles I‚Äôve worked on I still get flustered when I see a lot of open white space and long answer stacks in the grid, even though experience has taught me that all it takes is enough crosses or good guesses to get one or two of the long entries and then there is enough information to make the puzzle unfold like a rose.  Sure enough, I got RETIRETHESIDE and TOENAILSCISSORS and was able to build the puzzle from the bottom up ‚Äî until I got to the top third that is.    Up top, I had screwed myself royally by filling in COFFEECAKES (based on the K from KAEL) for 1A.  My ignorance of all things car-related also led to my entering El Dorado, instead of ELCAMINO (Chevy,  Cadillac what‚Äôs the diff, they both begin with C).  Apologies to our resident car buff Grant for this bit of automotive ignorance.  Having sorted that out I tried coffee maker before finally stumbling on WAFFLEMAKER and was able to cruise to a reasonable Saturday finish.

Favorite entry: GOODSPELLERS

I got DAB by recalling old Brylcreem ads, ‚ÄúA little dab‚Äôll do ya.‚Äù

Good puzzle.  First Saturday I've gotten in six weeks.

Last square I got was STUPA/PUTTEES cause I haven't heard of either of those and they phonetically work with any vowel.
Fun, challenging AND quick. Nice.

Yikes that was a toughie!  It went pretty quickly once I dug in, but it was still hard to complete for me.  Cera was of course the starting gimme, but every last answer felt hard-won.

Oh, not El Dorado and Lea Salonga?  Close quarters, close at hand, close something.  Not toenail clippers?  So very many dead ends.

I'm sure we will hear how Naticky Stupa and Puttees was, because it durn sure was!

A real workout for me.  Surprised XWStats only has it as "Hard" at this writing...

For SONYREADERS:  Can we put a moriatorium on including obscure-ish products that have been off the market for more than a decade?  This is bringing flashbacks to seeing HBO GO in crosswords way after HBO changed the name.

A nice Saturday puzzle: fun, bright, and fresh. 

When your top 2 rows are waffle maker and macaroni salad, it's time to get comfy and enjoy the ride üòÑ
Some of the fill here felt a bit clunky, namely GENUSANDSPECIES and GOODSPELLERS. Sappho and RETIRETHESIDE were definite high points though. We‚Äôll call it a very well balanced solving experience.

This one took some GRIT. About half of it felt hard and half came very quickly. Somehow I finished up about 20% faster than my average. Some of that may have been some lucky semi-educated guessing that worked out. 

I thought it was a fun one! The grid looked a little intimidating to me when I first opened it, but I also love all the stacks on stacks and space, so it was also exhilarating.

I have to admit I was a little bit annoyed when I entered wordSPELLERS and very, very happy to see I was wrong about that stinker. üòÜ

Sounded like it was the greenest of paint! Happily it didn't last too long before I saw the error of my ways.

When I saw how few black squares there were I decided to change my usual solve strategy which is to go through all the across clues quickly, then all the down clues quickly and from there work with footholds.  

Today I started with the short words, words of 3 or 4 or 5 letters, then tried to build on any of those answers. Once stuck there then I went through all the across and down answers.  Don't know if it helped, but I completed the puzzle in 43% less time than average.
just a fantastic puzzle. bravo!
Happy birthday! Thanks for that. The northwest part stumped me until "Homo sapiens e.g." Just popped into my head, then everything else fell into place. Bravo.

Happy Birthday Mark!
Six years was worth the wait.
I had to solve from the bottom up, like some other commentators. The top was one of those puzzles I just had to stare at for awhile and hoped something magically popped in (and GOWNS before FASTS and ASEAT before ASPOT didn‚Äôt help). Had LON, FRAY and MEDIAN and nothing else for a long while. I guess MISSILETEST finally helped give me a foothold? 
Loved the TOENAILSCISSORS clue. Don‚Äôt remember SONYREADERS but guessable. That and RETIRETHESIDE aren‚Äôt going to enthrall our non-American solvers‚Äîit means getting the last player out in a baseball inning. Andrzej, you get a pass on those but not STUPA because I know you played the Civilization video game as much as I did. Yeah, that would have been a Natick for me too if not for that.
I thought ‚Äúensnare for‚Äù was a bit clunky but the rest of the clues seemed spot on, challenging but fair. Best Saturday challenge in a long while for me.
At first glance, all the white spaces were intimidating, but it all fell in place nicely. Thank you for a great puzzle.

This seemed easy for a Saturday. Maybe it was because I solved it on my PC where I can read the clues without straining my eyes and made far fewer typos than on my phone. It was interesting and fresh with distinctive cluing that made me see some words and phrases in a different light.
For those who found PUTTEES a problem, wait until someone decides to try the obliquely related ‚Äúpugarees‚Äù

My flyspecking blind spot today was ASeaT instead of ASPOT.  Somehow my addled brain didn't notice GENUSANDSeECIES might have something wrong with it, and SaL ANGE's career has yet to take off.

Welcome back, Mr. Diehl, and thank you.  This Saturday was just right for a cozy Friday evening.  It must have been nice to find that you haven't lost your touch!
Smooth sailing for lower 2/3 - got stuck with dominANtSPECIES for a while. Anyone else end up with that for a bit?
A good, tough saturday. Had to check the comments to save my streak

I always read Wordplay after I complete the puzzle, just to see what clues were tricky, what the constructor has to say, etc. I'm not expecting to laugh out loud at the columnist's comments. Well done Caitlin, you had me giggling throughout!

That was a great Saturday puzzle. Did start with LESvOS as ŒõŒ≠œÉŒ≤ŒøœÇ would be phonetically transliterated but then gave in to get DADBODS. 

Few factoids that gave one the feeling that one  could get stuck but crosses were mostly evident. STUPA/PUTTEES cross fell last but without too much effort. 

Otherwise clever clues abounded. I liked MISSILETEST and RAINING best. 

Not a Waffle person so I had coffeemaker for the longest time. 

A most enjoyable Saturday morning puzzle 

Thanks.

"We should probably put another name before the species."
"Oh, you're a genus!"

(I told my family about this one.)

Anyone care to explain 44D STE ? Not complaining, just perplexed. 

Thanks

Bottom half warm and welcoming and top half icy and inhospitable (but in a clever, griddy way).

Always an invigoratingly disorienting experience when a puzzle has such strikingly divergent levels of geographic difficulty.  

I wonder how often it's by design.

A good 'un. The lower half was definitely more approachable but the top half unlocked fairly easily on the crosses. I solved quicker than usual for a Saturday, but didn't feel shortchanged on the difficulty aspect.
Lovely. Was pretty blocked on the top... but carved the right side out and all went well. 46min. Thank you, Mark!

All the long horizontal spinners scared me, so I abandoned my usual routine and started with the Downs. This turned out to be a good strategy, as I gained enough letters to figure out  MACARONI SALAD and TOENAIL SCISSORS pretty quickly. It was still tough going (STUPA had me in a STUPOR!) but a few lookups kept me from being hoisted by my own PUTTEE and I finished in OPTIMAL time.

Happy birthday, Mark. The spelling bee clue made me smile.

[The state a boxer may be in when the fight is over]
STUPOR

[The state Rocky Balboa may be in when the fight is over]
STUPA

I didn't have a problem with the STUPA - PUTTEES crossing since I was sort of familiar with Stupas and managed to figure out Puttees. The fact that it's derived from the Hindi word for bandages was an interesting bit of trivia I learned today!

But i did have trouble with the KAEL - SOLANGE crossing... that was my personal natick! Needed to look both up. That whole section was a mess for me. Didn't help that I'd entered EL dorado confidently lol

Overall a tough but fun Saturday! Loved the cluing for TOE SCISSORS and  GOOD SPELLERS... made me smile :)
What a fine Saturday. Nicely stacked, white as the noonday sun over the New Mexico desert, and with interesting fill to boot. Thanks, Mark.
There is an extra space in the clue for 26 down, between "as some".
Hard for me. But lots of fun. Once I got going. Thanks, Mark! Happy Saturday, y‚Äôall!

I found the puzzle very hard yet in the end I solved it in Friday time - curious. I needed to look up one thing when I did not get my gold star - and sure enough, I had made an error in the military leg wraps - I know their name in Polish ("onuce") but not in English. 

By now I've had enough experience with NYT puzzles that my guesses as to the many late-week unknows turn out to be correct most of the time. That sure helped today with the trivia, slang and sport terms.

I enjoyed the solve.

However, to satisfy bloodthirsty Tim in the UK, here goes:

If I wanted to fall asleep over a simplistic grid peppered with demotic Americanisms, I'd turn to USA Today. I'd tell the constructor to "Do better" - if I believed they could.
ELdorado instead of ELCAMINO tied up that sector for quite a while. Just about everything sounds plausible to me for a car model‚Ä¶ particularly when called a ‚Äúclassic‚Äù

Despite having owned one back in the early years, I sat for a minute wondering if the Nook (also 4 letters) was discontinued 12 years ago which I guess maybe suggests that Barnes and Noble is losing in the marketing game.

OUTSTANDING Saturday puzzle.  Minimal PPP, tough but fair.  Loved this one!

TIL that Corvette and El Camino have the same number of letters.

Happy Birthday, Mark!

I didn't recognize your name, but I will next time.  Excellent puzzle with a nice wide open grid.

I really got myself in a bind with A SeaT, KAal, EL doradO, SOLoman.  Maybe I thought there was a new mononymous singer who named himself after Solomon Burke.  What a fun mess to untangle.  I really wanted GENUS AND SPECIES, but my crosses told me otherwise.  Got it sorted out, but it took some time.

Like many others, I struggled over the STUPA/PUTTEES crossing.  I probably spent the last 4 minutes of my solve agonizing over which letter belonged.  Each vowel was entered, studied for both words, and erased a couple of times until U won the contest.  Not fully confident, but STUPA sounded the best.

What an interesting grid; lots of stuff I had to guess at; MACARONI SALAD for one,  I‚Äôve only ever called it generic pasta salad,  plus the usual SPORTS references, but they were all gettable with the downs and a bit of head scratching.
PUTTEES a rare gimme. I love the sound of the word, if not the reason behind the need. 

My Grandma spirit has well and truly established itself. I‚Äôve just spring cleaned my son‚Äôs already perfectly clean home, ahead of the little prince‚Äôs arrival. And I HATE cleaning. What‚Äôs happening to me? I‚Äôll be carrying Werthers toffees in my pocket next, rather than Alpaca pellets and the odd mini bottle of craft gin. Gah.

Having lived in Charlotte, NC, for almost 30 years, I confidently entered CLT for 45D, since it (airport code) used as the abbreviation for the city in almost everything. Obviously, I never watched an NBA game while living there.

I so glad to see that this is considered to be a solid Saturday puzzle, and not yet another example of my struggling when others are snuggling.  (That doesn't quite work, but I liked the "uggling" connection, and, I suppose if this were a pre-bed ritual, it might be not totally stupid.)

And yet, I didn't struggle with it, exactly, but I sure did have a lot of answers that I needed to change:  ELdoradO, ASeaT before ASPOT, WAFFLEcAKEs, I was sure the last three letters of 14A was going to be "ape", nOway before GODNO, aint before NARY, I was sure somehow INCISORS was going to be a part of TOENAILSCISSORS...it goes on and on.  

So today, for me was an exercise in sniffing out reasonable but wrong answers.  I think that makes a puzzle pretty difficult, even if the eventual right answer is pretty obvious once determined.  The exception to that, of course, is PUTTEES, which is brand new to me.  (I think STUPA came out of the mist and clouds at some point).

Really like Pauline KAEL being in the puzzle, even if she did hate "2001:  A Space Odyssey".  Everyone's entitled to a few bad misjudgements.
I solved in less than half my average time, yet it didn‚Äôt feel easy. I had only a few answers after my first pass and was able to build on those. That was the rewarding aspect of this puzzle.

Best to pre-measure the waffle batter into little Dixie-cups, or else the gluttonous guests will over-fill the press, and the batter will leak out and make a big mess, which the buffet attendant will have to clean up. Don't forget to tip. *** The moon has long since set; the Pleiades are gone; now half the night is spent, yet here I lie‚Äîalone. --Michael R. Burch (Well, not entirely alone--there's always tomorrow's NYT XW to help while away the insomniac night.) *** *** Don't like that? Here's 40+ other versions, including two "expansions" by A. E. Housman: https://tinyurl.com/yxvfs6py Or the perhaps "graphic novel" version: https://tinyurl.com/53jckemk *** *** *** From A to B to C(ampion, Thomas) and his LUTE: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zUv8D0KUCz4&list=RDzUv8D0KUCz4&start_radio=1 (Hi, @Sam!)

There are END keys on PCs????

I had the E, and thought Esc would be a very controversial answer, given the "seldom-used" in the clue.

Finished the puzzle today in around 40 minutes.  Upon getting the star and music the official time was 30 minutes longer.  Is anyone else having problems with the timer?  Some days the finishing times are six or seven hours. Not a superstar -- but not that slow!

Hi, Mark. I really enjoyed your puzzle and look forward to more from you. I am a relative newbie NYT puzzler (only solving consistently for a year) so I get a little intimidated on weekend puzzles;  however, this one was so satisfying! Not typical solves, and challenging , but I finished it earlier than my average and no clues! I think our brains must work similarly. Happy  Birthday!

Interesting how my puzzle time these days is almost invariably well below average. 

I feel like I'm living in Lake Wobegon...

Did this puzzle feel fresh?  That is, did you feel like you ran into many answers you‚Äôve never seen before?  

Well it is.  Amazingly is.  This puzzle has eight answers of 11 letters or more, and every one is a NYT answer debut.  That includes all six answers of the top and bottom stacks and those two long downs at 7D and 19D.  Wow!

There are actually 11 debuts.  Not all have zing, but, IMO, many do, such as MACARONI SALAD, ROPE INTO, WAFFLE MAKER, and GOOD SPELLERS.

New answers and their clues remove the easy gets that come from having seen them before in puzzles.  They happify the brain by giving it new territory to conquer.

Mark has been making Times puzzles for 42 years, and it‚Äôs clear he‚Äôs sharp as ever, crafting this uber-low 62-worder with plenty of GRIT and yes, pulsing with freshness.

BTW, I love those photo-album corners! 

Mark, I found your puzzle satisfying and richly punctuated with pleasurable moments. Thank you, and don‚Äôt wait so long, please, before your next one!
KIng Phillip Catches Old Fish Gets Sicks comes in handy 50+ years after 7th grade Science!
I'm surprised no one has commented on the clever crossing of STUPA and its (near) homophone STUPOR. There is an old joke about an intoxicated monk falling into a....

Yikes! This looked like a tough one with so much white space, and it was. Missed my Saturday average, but the challenge was worth it. 

Starting with the acrosses, I got all the way to 31A (DAB) or maybe 37A (LUTE) before filling one in.

I did better on the lower half, but it was still a matter of getting one or two words for a toehold, then branching out from there. Downs more accessible than the acrosses.

No Naticks for me, although I've never heard of SOLANGE, ROTH, or STUPA. SOLANGE/KAEL might qualify, but who doesn't know Pauline KAEL?

For 1A I was stuck with coffeEMAKER for a long time. I eventually realized it had to be WAFFLE, but I tend to avoid those at hotels. I like waffles, but not with the ersatz syrup you'll find at the breakfast bar. (Note my home state.)

Definitely a worthy challenge to start the weekend. Thanks!

Were this a puzzle, without cross
in a STUPOR I'd have been lost.
Yet every ODDITY I met
shared A SPOT with some sure bet.

So, with GRIT, luck and ACUITY
t'was NARY a fatal ODDITY!
So, to those in the MIRE or on the FRAY,
BLESS Y'ALL and have a lovely day.

Editors:  how does one reach a human regarding the box puzzle (pink)?  i have sent in comments about real disallowed words for years but none  have ever been acknowledged and the words have never been allowed.  One that is a favorite could often fit: YAR.  In the 1939 movie The Philadelphia Story, Katherine Hepburn says to Cary Grant about her sailboat
‚ÄúMy, she was yar...It means, uh...easy to handle, quick to the helm, fast, right. Everything a boat should be, until she develops dry rot.‚Äù   This is searchable on Google.  There are other spellings and an etymology.  As a sailor, I always loved this romantic scene and to use this word.

It's a good morning for poetry: That man is peer of the gods, who face to face sits listening to your sweet speech and lovely laughter. It is this that rouses a tumult in my breast. At mere sight of you my voice falters, my tongue is broken. Straightway, a delicate fire runs in my limbs; my eyes are blinded and my ears thunder. Sweat pours out: a trembling hunts me down. I grow paler than grass and lack little of dying. --William Carlos Williams, 1958 https://tinyurl.com/2u6f96ty
Nice for a Saturday

I said this early in last night's comments, but the thread got really long, so I wanted to repost it more prominently.

I guarantee that most of the complaints today will be the PUTTEES/STUPA cross.
____

I then got a lot of "not me" answers.  I posted the following  just a few minutes ago.


I knew I'd get a lot of "not me's" on this one, but a few points:

1. I never called it a Natick. But I'd say that details about a religion that not many English speakers practice and a makeshift legging worn over 100 years ago in the trenches of Belleau Wood are pretty esoteric knowledge.  Surely there are many in the crowd who know one, the other, or both, but just as surely, there are going to be many--maybe most--who don't know either.

2. If you have to run the alphabet (or even the vowels) in a tournament, that's not a clean solve.  You get only one guess.

3. Early results are bearing me out.

I think great themeless puzzle creators descended from waffle makers. They slowly and warmly squeeze our minds into their mold, and we end up smiling, with dimples.



Enjoyed it, like the very sharpest toenail scissors (?).

Yowch! That was a toughie for me.  I was pleased with how far I got this time 4/5‚Äôs and 30 minutes before understanding that my skills are still limited. 

I believe it was a fair puzzle.  

And as I like to remind myself, I really can‚Äôt be a know it all if I really don‚Äôt know it all!!

I'm definitely going to be in a minority here but I found today's puzzle incredibly difficult and incredibly unenjoyable. 

I didn't know much of the trivia and the entire top half turned into a complete slog. Must just not have been on the constructor's wavelength. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
Fun solve but not challenging enough. Completed in 18 minutes. Now I have to figure out to do with the rest of my Saturday since it‚Äôs too cold to go outside
Had to look up the critic, singer, and both authors. Oh well.  The clues were fun.  NOWAY instead of GODNO was a mess. SPORTSODDS didn't help much either. Cheers.
I thought I was lost. The puzzle looked vast and empty and unfillable....and then my future wife (17A) saved me!
Pleasantly surprised when I filled-in the last letter and got the "Congratulations music"
Got the lower half ok but the top just wouldn‚Äôt budge.
I‚Äôm here on a weekend to express my astonishment at GENUS AND SPECIES, because I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever been tripped up so hard by a conjunction.

Another streak comes to its end, done in by my ignorance of both STUPA and PUTTEES. Didn't know SOLANGE or KAEL either, but there the L was an obvious choice. When two unknowns intersect at a vowel ... well, good luck with that!

Fine Saturday puzzle. Especially liked "Long shot practice" for MISSILETEST.

@Jacob From your Thursday comment: I absolutely do not get why a trip to the Hague would be a punishment. I've spent time in the Dutch city and it's a lovely place. Are you thinking of somewhere else? Hope you see this today
Loved every minute of this. Thanks and congrats to the constructors!

WAFFLE cakes instead oF MAKER
EL dorado instead of CAMINO
Save me A seat, not SPOT

I don‚Äôt think I could have engaged in more self-sabotage in NE if I had tried. Thank goodness I‚Äôm old enough to remember Pauline KAEL!  Tough but fun!

I‚Äôm glad I had SCISSORS before I got TOENAIL or I‚Äôd have been stuck trying to fit CLIPPERS into the Downs.

When I started I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd finish. I think DAB and Y‚ÄôALL were the only ones I got on my first pass of the Across clues, but then I got going and it flowed well.
Never heard the expression RETIRE THE SIDE, so the very last letter I entered was the T in the middle of it. I'm still not positive what STE means, but I'm guessing "suite"?

The grid alone was enough for me to give this puzzle a thumbs-up.  The beautiful spiral with the lovely stacks at the top and bottom.  I hope everyone took a few seconds to appreciate it.

The level of difficulty was well in the Goldilocks "just right" zone, although it felt a little on the Friday side to me.
YMMV.

Plenty of fresh answers and cluing with little stale fill.  Very nice!  
My favorite was "Long shot practice".  It had me thinking about "Hail Marys" in football.  And that it crossed with the clue "Misdirect" was especially enjoyable.

Overall, a very satisfying experience.  Thanks, Mark Diehl!

I wonder whether anyone has ever approached the emus' overlords with the suggestion of implementing a search function here in order to peruse comments by specific posters.

This would be appealing on many levels.

In the fancy hotels, if you get the Lumberjack‚Äôs Breakfast (which I think also includes macaroni salad), does ‚Äúretire the side‚Äù mean you eat all the waffles?

Asking for a friend who never eats in fancy hotels.

One semi-cheat to finish -- with a wild guess at the big "Huh?" PUTTEES/STUPA cross that was right,

The semi-cheat was typing "Chevy El C" into Google and getting CAMINO.  I always feel slightly less guilty when I use info I've already gleaned rather than just typing in the entire clue.

Two important write-overs:  OPTIMUM to OPTIMAL and save me A SEAT to save me A SPOT.  No way else I was getting GENUS AND SPECIES which is just plain wonderful.

Because it's Saturday, I spared myself a lot of trouble by not writing in TOENAIL CLIPPERS and RETIRE BATTERS without checking crosses.  Both were my original impulses. And now a question that I hope many of Y'ALL will answer:

Does anyone here use a TOENAIL SCISSORS?  I don't think they work at all.  Only CLIPPERS work, IMHO.

A terrific stack-y grid.  (Love these -- but they're always very hard.) Tough cluing.  I found this an engrossing and worthy Saturday challenge.

With @Bill doing such a good job praising the poet of LESBOS, I think we can take a moment or two to praise the great New Yorker writer, Pauline KAEL, not only the greatest film critic, but one of the greatest essayists of our time (if your conception of "our time" is the second half of the 20th century).
I didn't always agree with her assessments of films, but her writing was always crisp and fresh and thought-provoking.  She taught me (and many others) how to be better viewers and better thinkers.

All my trials popped up in the NE. In so far as Saturday puzzles go, today had more flow than ebb‚Ä¶Always enjoy baseball clues even if it‚Äôs the eve of the ‚ÄúBig Game.‚Äù‚Ä¶I ruffled all the emus feathers earlier this week when my comment and link relative to ‚Äòoglers‚Äô checking things out. THIS IS Glen Campbell on stage with a ballad chock full of ‚ÄúTrue GRIT.‚Äù SOL(ong)ANGE, BRRRRRRRU https://youtu.be/bKN7fVhWg80?si=8Ox-zcVeAfkn7xFp
I‚Äôll have you know I use the END key all the time. ‚ÄúSeldom used‚Äù! Pah

Mark Diehl hangs a head on the trophy wall! 
 I couldn't get past the EL DORADO/ "Save me A SEAT" error, given that the crossings were just Killers.  The Grammy winner, the author, the "recognition"..... GENUS AND SEE-----, I could never get past the roadblock.  Maybe if I took a break?  But that's not going to happen today.  

I doubt my "Comment-in-Chief" ever got released yesterday, after I committed the unpardonable sin of bashing ANGI (in all its iterations.)  

19D made me think (just briefly) that we were speaking of a quilting party, and GRANDMOTHER would have fit (into the grid, not as a descriptor for the MOL) but I had to take it all out except for the G and the R.  

I'll have to settle for being proud of how much I did get in this puzzle, and bask in my rep as a GOOD SPELLER.  
(When I was typing papers back in the day, I charged 35 cents a page OR 50 cents a page to correct spelling and punctuation.  Heh ...usually got the higher pay.)

All Y'ALL have a good weekend.  See ya in the funny papers!

A quick question: in my stats, it says my "solve rate" is 99.8%. I've been doing the puzzle for a little over a year, so I guess that means I've started one, and didn't finish it? But I went through the entire archive, and couldn't find one partially completed. So I looked again. Nope. Is there any way to find out what puzzle it thinks I haven't finished? 

I would think a more interesting stat would be percentage of puzzles finished without clues.

If there's a better place to post this question, where would that be?
Spent about 15 minutes on the NW corner-the rest wasn't that hard.

While it would be tricky and slow but technically possible to make a hedge from ‚Äúa (single) yew‚Äù tree, I think a better interpretation of the clue is to consider we are using a single binomial, such as Taxus canadensis (variety nonitalicus because I don‚Äôt how to italicize things here), but multiple individuals.

I don't know how many people are familiar with Bob and Ray, but they were comedians from the last century who perfected deadpan when Stephen Wright was still in diapers. I highly recommend them (all 3, tbh) when you need a respite from today's news. Anyway, Bob and Ray had a routine about PUTTEES that I found quite helpful when attempting to solve today's absolutely fabulous crossword: https://bit.ly/3LWbTZ1. On another note, our short, free, ad-free, family-friendly and we like to think hilarious in a Bob-and-Ray-sense podcast, Jean & Mike Do The New York Times Crossword, is still going strong: it's available wherever you get your podcasts.
I‚Äôm slightly concerned about how quickly my brain filled in [As good as it gets] with OPenbAr.

Happy Birthday, Mark and welcome back! I love when I look at a puzzle and have nothing, and then before you know it, I am going through all the vowels to complete (StUpa-pUttees)
Thanks and enjoy the day!

After my comment yesterday, I want to congratulate Mark Diehl for a terrific Saturday puzzle! I look forward to the challenge on Fridays and Saturdays, and recently they have seemed a bit on the easier side. Today was just the right kind of workout. Hardly any Naticky proper nouns, except for my personal experience with STUPA/PUTTEES, where the U was easily found with a vowel run at the end. 

Almost all of the answers were common words or phrases, but the clues were sparkling, fresh and clever. My favorites were 29D‚Äôs heavy drinkers in a STUPOR, 19D‚Äôs bee‚Äôs GOODSPELLER and 32D‚Äôs soft-physique DADBODS.

Thank you, Mark, and happy birthday!
I went from the COFFEE CAKES to the COFFEE MAKER to the WAFFLE MAKER. Big breakfast!

Happy Birthday, Mark! I‚Äôm late to the comments because I had a hard time completing your fine puzzle. After a slow start last night (so much white space, so many long answers), I finally cracked it @6am this morning. When I read Caitlin‚Äôs column I was not surprised to learn that you are a prolific puzzlemaster. The many positive comments and related/unrelated threads here reflect the quality of your work and indicate that you put the crowd in a good mood with a proper Saturday.

I found that tough but quick, "Whoosh fun" (Rothlein, 2026). 

I had to pause and admire "One of many in a bee." It could refer to a quilting square, to one part of a compound eye, or to something concerning words. After respectfully leaving that blank, I found the rest of the puzzle filled with small, brief, delights. 

"Homo sapiens" was baffling until it had enough crossings and the woolen leggings were a complete mystery even after crossings. In fact, the second E in PUTTEES was my last fill. I was relieved to see that Caitlin explained that one because it was a potential rabbit hole that could have eaten up my Saturday.

Going to "whoosh" off and turn back to some qualitative analysis I keep avoiding.

I found yesterday's crossword to be quite a bit thornier than today's and I wonder whether others felt the same.

I always find that random "clicking with the constructor" factor to be very interesting. Both puzzles were very smooth, enjoyable solves.

Now I'm gonna sit here in the frigid Mid-Atlantic and pray my house doesn't blow away like the Wizard of Oz. The howling is pretty much constant.

First off, Happy Birthday, Mark Diehl, and welcome back! This felt like a perfect Saturday challenge. I think I made every single error possible on my initial guesses ü§£ 
ASeaT, nOway, TOENAIL clIppeRS, aint, luSH,  SPORTS oddS, and I was convinced that [Former e-book device‚Ä¶] was a Nook, so I removed BODS after DAD ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I was really feeling like a FOOL!! Slowly my errors got corrected and the grid filled in. I have recently become reacquainted with MACARONI SALAD from a local Hawaiian restaurant that I love. It‚Äôs nothing like the version I grew up with that I detested for some reason. Someone earlier in the comments mentioned that they refer to it as pasta salad, which is technically true, but I classify them differently. In my experience (which is obviously not the same as others) pasta salad is typically made with fusilli, rotini or farfalle pasta in an oil based dressing and macaroni salad is made with elbow pasta specifically and has a mayonnaise based dressing. 
As for WAFFLE MAKER, it is a staple with my kids in every single hotel we visit and it didn‚Äôt even occur to me as the answer ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Kudos to Mark for tricking me at every turn. I really enjoyed this one.

Will it be CHEVETTE or CHEVELLE? Hmm, probably neither, given that "Chevy" is in the clue, but it probably starts with a C. Well, it sorta does.

Unlike so many here, I knew both STUPA and PUTTEES, but Pauline KAEL? Now that's maximum strength NYCentric. "Not fair, in a way" for RAINING was my favorite.
My 'lil darlings that needed slaying were SPORTStaTS and OPTIMum in an otherwise pretty smooth outing.  Thanks for the very excellent challenge.
Crossword gods heard my complaints yesterday about easy weekend puzzles and decided to deliver this.
Good tough Saturday. One hour and 7 minutes with no lookups.
I'm surprised at how many puzzlers were stumped by STUPA. I'm glad I knew that one since I would have had no chance with PUTTEES!
Who uses a scissors on their toes?
https://trends.google.com/explore?q=stupa%2Cputtees&date=now%207-d&geo=US

What a great puzzle!!  I was pretty much stymied until the mid-section -- thought I was falling FLAT but Michael CERA convinced me I was READYTOGO, and suddenly I had the GRIT to carry on.  Loved the clues for the low digits and many bees.  The NW corner had me stumped for the longest time, but somehow managed to finish in under 27 min with no look ups.  Perfect Saturday work-out!!
For me, a perfect rather tough Saturday puzzle from Mark Diehl (with whom I once had breakfast about 40 years ago).

Happy Birthday, Mark. Thanks for sharing your gifts today. A great puzzle that I enjoyed solving ABM. A few misdirects and head scratchers, but your thoughtful, natick-free crosses saved the day.  Never thought I would see WAFFLEMAKER and TOENAILSCISSORS in the same puzzle, although both are nearly impossible to use.

I love love LOVED this puzzle from start to finish. The long spanners were fantastic, and the cluing struck that perfect balance of being tricky yet fair. It took me multiple passes before I felt like I had a real foothold, and even then it made me work for every section - in the best way.  A perfect Saturday puzzle. Thank you, Mr. Diehl!

I think this was the first time I didn't have to jump around on a Saturday puzzle. Not that it was a breeze, it just flowed with consistent pacing, fresh fill, and many mind-meld moments from top to bottom. Thank you, Mark, and happy birthday!
coFFeEMAKER made the NW almost impossible for me üò´ I shall eat waffles as penance.
Curio shop treasure - Oddity? That's not an item, that's their stock-in-trade.

Great puzzle, and a fun solve. The first answer I confidently filled in was 36A, and I thought "Oh, no, here we go!" But I worked on it steadily and ended up with a solve time that wasn't much longer than my Saturday PB!

Though I‚Äôve heard the word PUTTEES many times in song, this is the first time I‚Äôve seen it written. The blue puttees were a regiment of soldiers from Newfoundland (before it was part of Canada) sent to join the allied forces in WW1. But since we have only black and white pictures of that time, you‚Äôll have to use your imagination. https://www.heritage.nf.ca/first-world-war/articles/recruiting-the-newfoundland-regiment.php
BTW, the over/under for tomorrow's game is 45.5 points.

Health update for @heathieJ and others here who have contemplated/shown interest a cardiac ablation to remedy Afib. It has been a good year since my ablation, a transformative year, one without my heart beating so fast I could not catch my breath. My resting heartbeat is now a steady 56 bpm. Yesterday I scaled the foothills of the Sandia, climbing 1400' during a five-mile hike, without fear of my heart going berserk.
I have also mastered the BiPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure, similar to CPAP) machine that I use to control my breathing due to central apnea (Electrical not mechanical problem). My oxygen level is now normal nearly always.
Now that the electricians have fixed my faulty wiring, and I no longer drink any alcoholic beverages, I have great energy and renewed mental ACUITY. I feel as if 70 really is just a number.
My advice: get the ablation, force yourself to master your breathing machines no matter how untenable using the contraption might seem, and quit drinking. You will feel so much better.

This was a rare solve-from-the-bottom-to-the-top puzzles for me. On my first pass, the only entries that I was confident about, strangely, were STUPA and PUTTEE. I have no idea where those two have been hiding in my brain. They were enough to open up the SW corner, though. STUPA suggested STUPOR, and the rest of the corner opened up. Whew!

I loved TOENAIL SCISSORS (initially CLIPPERS because, hey, who uses scissors?) and RAINING for [Not fair, in a way]. My favorite, though, was GENUS AND SPECIES.  What a lovely bit of cluing! Simple and open-ended. I didn't see the right answer until I had both WAFFLE MAKER and MACARONI SALAD and a handful of crosses.

It's a good thing that I don't pay attention to my solving time. This was one puzzle I could solve slowly and savor.  Thank you.

Late puzzle find inspired by YALL. With a bit of counting realized that that... YALLCOMEBACKNOW ...is 15 letters. And, yep - it was answer once - in a Monday from February 4, 2008 by Dave Mackey and Tracy Mackey. Two other answers in that one: DONTBEASTRANGER DROPINANYTIME Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/4/2008&g=59&d=A ....
It took getting rid of SS Camaro to start solving the top part of this puzzle, which I held onto for quite a while.
Absolutely brutal. Fabulous puzzle!

Despite stalling in the N, I came in well under average. I enjoyed the interesting fill throughout.

Was there a mini lit theme in the S? Sappho, Hesse, Oberon, fiction, reader, speller...

I gave one of my sons the middle name Auberon, of which Oberon is a variant. It means both "elf king" and "noble bear." I got it from the book Little, Big, which I would highly recommend.

17A x 9D: NATICK.

Fun ones in there, though.

WAFFLEcAKEs did me no favors. Also had ELdoradO for way too long, tExT instead of FEAT, LyrE instead of LUTE. 

I got GRIT right off the bat, but it didn't help me at all, so I removed it. Finally got it from the crosses and saw that the answer was ... GRIT. 

All signs of a great puzzle üôÇ
Great puzzle, but STUPA crossed with PUTTEES is just plain evil!
Another great trivia puzzle

In case our Antarctic puzzlers are still playing along ‚Äì I thought of them this morning listening to an author interview, where one of her essays reflects on the South Polar Times. Apparently it was published to help distract expeditioners during the long winters. (While it is summer there right now, we here in the northeast are in need of some warm distractions from the current deep freeze!) https://www.npr.org/2026/02/07/nx-s1-5602916/anne-fadiman-discusses-her-book-frog-and-other-essays

A brilliant puzzle! I thoroughly enjoyed it. 

It opened up early for me when I got 1A and 12A right off the bat, which helped immensely in getting 14A from the crossings. 19D was my favorite clue by far.

I finished 17 minutes under my average, surprising for a Saturday.

Thanks Mr. Diehl; I was happy to see your byline after a long hiatus!

I had a bit of a challenge finding a toehold here, and was pretty far into the south before I had any fills at all -- and ended up solving this pretty much SE to NW...still once I found my way in it went fairly quickly, and I solved around 40 percent under my Saturday average (and, great for me as far as time, less than a minute over the median time on XWStats). I appreciated a number of the clues: 14A "Homo sapiens, e.g." for GENUS AND SPECIES. I got the SPECIES fairly quickly and then spent some time thinking, "okay, what sort of species?" Wonderful clue of the answer. I also appreciated 43A, "They make low digits smaller" for TOENAIL SCISSORS...and was glad I got the SCISSORS before TOENAIL since, if I had solved it the other way around I would have gotten stuck trying to figure out the crossing fills for TOENAil clippers."

One small bit: This may be just me, but given the sacking of the Washington Post this week, Pauline KAEL gave me a twinge. Yes, I know she wrote for the New Yorker and no the WaPo, but the two events reminded me of so many things we have lost in the way of excellence in print.
In one of those huh??? moments, I instantly knew 30 down was puttees, but I have no idea how I knew it or where I learned it.
coffeecakes...wafflecakes....wafflemaker....Yowser!...great Saturday challenge!

MAIN Street ends at Sleeping Beauty Castle?! Main Street!!! Not knowing Sony readers or having heard the phrase "retire the side" I was racking my brain for some apt Disney-related street name for ages, possibly eons. Oof. 

What you don't know can, indeed, hurt you.

A good challenge. I had FRAY, LON and Esc to start but pretty much had to get to the bottom to find a toehold in the classics with FAIRY, LESBOS and HESSE. I managed a solve slowly from the bottom and finished on my initial mistake which by then had been changed to ENt. Obviously I‚Äôm unfamiliar with PC keys! 
As I didn‚Äôt know what a GENUSANT SPECIES is I figured it must be END.
Puttees and Stupa... sheesh.

So many mistakes in the top middle and left that dragged this out to 90 minutes for me. Esc instead of END, even though I doubted Esc because it‚Äôs not rarely used. Instead of GODNO I had nOway from the start, then hOlup when I wanted humanoidspecies. Never heard of MACARONISALAD so that slowed me down too.

I had the second half of 5 of the 6 long ones well before I got the first halves, although the bottom half and middle weren‚Äôt too bad.

I started at this game some time in October and I had two Sat gold stars in Nov, one the first week of December and none since. I just looked and all three of those were much faster than today. I wouldn‚Äôt have thought beginners luck would be a thing for crosswords, unless the luck is that they happened to be very easy-for-the-day editions, which is probably likely.

I enjoyed this more than yesterday, which is probably why I stuck with it longer.

Query: Why do they call them ROSYBOAS? They aren't any shade of red at all.
COMMENS: The constructor GOT me with the bees. Ooooh that stings. I could live without the disgusting TOENAILSCISSORS. Bleah.

SEPARATE COMMENT: Today's Connections was completely unfair. I put in things that went together but because I included the X sign, I had a no-go. The thing I hate about this game is that it's really what's inside the creator's head and it's not always logical. A LOT of natiks too!

Some of the clues today were not the greatest. N*** is hardly a colloquial word. On the bright side, the Thursday CWs have been much more enjoyable the last couple of weeks, without all the tricky silliness that renders them a drag.

Wow, that grid was intimidating at first glance. Remain calm, I reminded myself.

Many misfires, like Corvette before ELCAMINO, seat before SPOT, luxe before POSH, Cyprus before LESBOS (although I thought that one was pretty iffy).

I filled in STUPA on my first pass, but I was hung up on SPORTSBETS. What kind of bets?? Oh, just sports, duh. And RETIRETHESIDE?? Why does baseball have so many terms that sound ridiculous as phrases themselves? Like "for the W" when win is easier to say than double-you. And a team from where, Charleston? Chattanooga? Charlotte? Champaign? Chamonix? My lack of sports knowledge led to that H being the last square. 

Very fun spanners, but the starting of TOE had me pretty worried. Is there some gruesome surgery I don't know about that makes toes smaller? Thank goodness, no, at least not today. 

I found it enjoyable from start to end, and I look forward to more from Mr Diehl.

I don't know where I learned about PUTTEES, but it was not from speaking with the WWI vets in my family (one of my father's older brothers, and my mother's stepfather).

I don't remember when I first learned STUPA, but I ran into it most recently yesterday in the archives.
Nice one today.  Thank you, and more like this, please.  All the pop culture trivia was solvable with cross clues.

Just here to say that End and Home are two of my most frequently used PC keys. There's no faster way to get to the end or beginning of a line or a document (when combined with Ctrl), or to make a selection (when combined with Shift). I use these constantly when programming, word processing, writing emails, etc. Kind of shocked that someone considered End being infrequently used "shared truth" enough for a crossword. Our country truly is divided...

One more late puzzle find. I'll probably re-post this one tomorrow. A Sunday from March 19, 1989 by Caroline G. Fitzgerald with the title: "Doin' the twist." Some theme clues and answers: "Betty Botta" BITOBETTERBUTTERBUYER "Mollusk merchant" SEASHORESHELLSELLER "Peter Piper" PECKOFPEPPERSPICKER "Caesar" SIGHINGSCISSORSSEIZER "Sister Suzie" SOLDIERSSHIRTSEWER Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=3/19/1989&g=111&d=A ...

Sure they are valid answers but not something one ever thinks of‚Ä¶ I really did not like the clue for 43A ‚Äú They make low digits smaller‚Äù TOENAILSCISSORS? What are you cutting your toes off? (I get the fact that they are trimming the nails). Poor clueing ESPECIALLY when so many of the crosses were brutal‚Ä¶

Um, I looked through a few comments and I have to say, very humbly, I thought this was the easiest Saturday puzzle in a long while.
I entered the last letter and bingo, no errors! Now please, I'm not one who brags, in fact I'm fairly shocked because I have written off the Saturday more than once. I have just quit and figured well it's beyond me, Sunday's sometimes is too, but, then Monday's is always right around the corner. 
I also have to say, all this week's puzzles were strangely fast solves. What's in the water (I'm always sipping on my ice water throughout the day) this week!
Did I make some sort of mental breakthrough?
Anyway, I'm feeling a little satisfied with myself, if I may, but, there's always next week and I'm sure some clever constructor will put me right back in my place.

At that juncture the program would set the flag for that puzzle saying it was either was or wasn't solved correctly on the first attempt, and update the statistic accordingly. Ok, two comments within a couple of inches about "green paint" -- what's that? I googled it, and not surprisingly only got ads for green paint. I thought I was dialed into all the lingo, so spill.

@Nora

Let me elaborate on Jennifer's answer.

Certain phrases are common collocations:  green energy, greengrocer, green salad, Greensleeves.  Green energy means more than green + energy.  A greengrocer specializes in what we call "greens".  A green salad is made from said greens, differentiated from, say, MACARONI SALAD.  Greensleeves is a song that has nothing to do with green or sleeves.

Similarly, latex paint, oil paint, tempera paint, wet paint.  These are specific categories of paint.

But  thick paint, good paint, excellent paint, green paint are not specific "things," they're just descriptions of paint.

Does that help?

JeffLeff ‚Äî¬†if you go to the online puzzle Archive (after choosing a year and month), the finished puzzles with be marked with a star. The puzzles that were begun but not finished will be marked otherwise.

commentBody:
@Francis
The nation now called Canada was set up by the Brits in 1867 and consisted of four provinces (cf. USian '13 colonies').  Before then, there were various settlements leading back through colonial times to indigenous civilizations on what was called by some 'Turtle Island.' Since 1867, we've been adding provinces and territories. 'Newfoundland & Labrador' (one province despite its bifurcated name) came aboard in 1949.

commentBody:
@jas
And a good thing too!

@Joe

What we've lost indeed.

It used to be that every little town in the country had an independent newspaper that specialized on that town.

There's a lot of discussion about how rural American has been forgotten--that's one way it's been forgotten.  No real news comes from them anymore.

@Francis I could go on at length about this. I spent part of my high school years in a small coal-mining/farming town in southeastern Ohio. For more than 150 years it had a weekly paper, which closed in 2021. The town is lucky enough that someone has begun an online, volunteer publication...but for the years between he shuttering of the paper and the appearance of the online publication, it was as if the town just ceased to exist.

I live now in the St. Louis area and have read the Post-Dispatch for decades -- starting when I was eight or nine, when we lived in Cincinnati, and my father took me with him when he did rounds at the hospital (he was a cardiologist) and would leave me in the doctor's lounge with four papers -- the Enquirer and three out of town papers: the Cleveland Plain Dealer, as he was from Cleveland, the New York Times, and the Post-Dispatch, since he'd gone to med school and done his residency in St. Louis. For that reason, the PD became important to me. For a few years n the late 90s and into the 2000s I freelanced for it largely because it was the Post, as the money was meager...but now it is vanishing...when Lee Enterprises bought it roughly  20 years ago, they turned it into essentially a small-town paper and who knows how much longer it will be around. They now no longer print the Monday edition and the new publisher announced this week that he wants to move it to the right politically.
